comment.author: 50915374@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66340104@N05] Yes the black one.  Wigs were big in the 60's.  The meaning of wearing them had changed from the 30, 40, and fifties.  Before it was mysterious if one was detected wearing one.  But the in the mid 60's, wigs for women and some men were big fashion accessories.

comment.author: 48447736@N00
comment._content: Yeah, it used to be worthwhile to fly. Actually trying to please the customers, imagine that. Well, you'll have to imagine it, because you'll never see it. Now it's just the experience of being jammed into seats designed by a one-armed, 82-lb engineer by angry, suspicious peanut vendors after having your prostate (or ovaries) checked by some pseudo-security drone who mostly wants to steal your iPad. Assuming your name hasn't magically gotten on the "no-fly" list for writing blog posts or being Cat Stevens. Driving is now my transport of choice. Even if it takes a week to get there. That's what can happen when political correctness and social paranoia control mass transport.

comment.author: 24822442@N05
comment._content: nice modeling group

comment.author: 15033184@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/fyngyrz] Your comment is spot on as we say in England. I can assume you are in the states? I have the most trouble when travelling there and Canada.
Why is there so much paranoia, I mean they haven't grasped that they are creating their own reality. The internet has undoubtedly become the most convenient way for crazy govts to spy on us and tell us where we were on such and such a date and to whom we were speaking and what was said, i'm over it.
I waited three hours to get through Vancouver airport to take that propellor aircraft 30 minutes down to Seattle. There was background checks, criminal records bureau, retinal scan and fingerprint lantern! Absolutely ridiculous.
You speak a lot of truth, thankyou.

comment.author: 65194676@N07
comment._content: My old former girlfriend worked for PSA and I still vividly recall that period and all the flights I used to fly with that wonderful airline. In fact, I still have her photo when she was featured on the front cover of the PSA magazine. You know, the one they have on the plane with the usual advertisements. Man, this photo really brings back the most wonderful time of my entire life!

Ah, let there be more style today, instead of peanuts you have to pay extra for...

comment.author: 65194676@N07
comment._content:
more to say.. My former girlfriend with PSA was far more attractive than any of those illustrated in this photo. I'm tempted to post the PSA Magazine cover with her on it, but in this day and age I probably end up in a lawsuit.

It's unfortunate that women today look so artificial or plastic compared to women of the 70's. Not sure if it's the newer style of make-up, facial piercings or tatts, but American women today just don't get it. Conversely, women in some European countries still manage to have that look' of the past era and its quite refreshing.
